revision.comment: Changing the Commons category from "Category:Saxon church in Valea Viilor" to "Category:Fortified Lutheran church in Valea Viilor, Sibiu"
revision.text:
{{Infobox religious building | name = Valea Viilor Fortified Church | native_name =Biserica fortificată din Valea Viilor | image = Valea Viilor Biserica fortificata.JPG | caption = | location = [[Valea Viilor]], Romania | geo = {{coord|46.083200|24.277055|display=inline,title}} | province = | religious_affiliation = [[Evangelical Church of Augustan Confession in Romania|Lutheran]] | consecration_year = | status = | functional_status = | heritage_designation = | website = | architecture = yes | architecture_type = [[Fortified church]] | architecture_style = [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] | groundbreaking = 14th century | year_completed = 16th century | specifications = no | designation1 = WHS | designation1_offname = {{nowrap|[[Villages with fortified churches in Transylvania]]}} | designation1_date = 1993 (17th [[World Heritage Committee|session]])
1999 (23rd [[World Heritage Committee|session]] – Extension) | designation1_number = [https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/596 596] | designation1_criteria = iv | designation1_type = Cultural | designation1_free1name = State Party | designation1_free1value = Romania | designation1_free2name = Region | designation1_free2value = {{nowrap|[[List of World Heritage Sites in Europe|Europe and North America]]}} | designation2 = Monument istoric | designation2_date = | designation2_offname = [[:Category:Historic monuments in Sibiu County|Historic monuments in Sibiu County]] | designation2_number = [[LMI Code]]: SB-II-a-A-12582 (RAN Code: 145970.01) | designation2_criteria = | designation2_type = architectural | designation2_free1name = Country | designation2_free1value = }} The '''Valea Viilor fortified church''' ({{lang-ro|Biserica fortificată din Valea Viilor}}; {{lang-de|Kirchenburg von Wurmloch}}) is a [[Evangelical Church of Augustan Confession in Romania|Lutheran]] [[fortified church]] in [[Valea Viilor]] (''Wurmloch''), [[Sibiu County]], in the [[Transylvania]] region of [[Romania]]. It was built by the [[Germans|ethnic German]] [[Transylvanian Saxon]] community at a time when the area belonged to the [[Kingdom of Hungary (1301–1526)|Kingdom of Hungary]]. Initially [[Roman Catholic]], it became Lutheran following the [[Protestant Reformation|Reformation]]. Together with the surrounding village, the church forms part of the [[villages with fortified churches in Transylvania]] [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]]. ==Description== [[File:Valea Viilor - Biserica 02.jpg|thumb|Church interior]] [[File:Valea Viilor Biserica fortificata (3).JPG|thumb|Altar]] ===Background and church=== There is evidence to suggest that an earlier [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] church existed in the village, as remnants could formerly be seen beneath the floor of the [[sacristy]]. This building is believed to have been 10 m long, less than half the length of the present church. The latter, in [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] style and dedicated to [[Saint Peter]],[[Vasile Drăguț]], ''Arta gotică în România'', p.127. Editura Meridiane, Bucharest, 1979 was begun in the 14th century. The small [[nave]] has a vaulted ceiling with a complex network of ribs, which rest on seven pairs of poles attached to the walls. The [[Choir (architecture)|choir]] has a ceiling of the same type. Built in 1528, the [[pulpit]] was produced in a period of transition from Gothic to [[Renaissance architecture|Renaissance]]. The church underwent modifications at the beginning of the 16th century: a defensive level featuring parapets was added atop the nave, while towers were built next to the north and south entrances. Next to each of these was a small round tower with a spiral staircase that reached the fortified level. A third tower, near the buttress at the southwest end of the nave, provided access to the [[Belfry (architecture)|belfry]], itself fitted with numerous and varied defense mechanisms. The choir was rebuilt as a three-story brick defensive tower with walls 1.5 m thick. A fourth level, which juts out slightly atop a row of [[corbel]]s and is supported by arches built between the [[buttress]]es, has a [[Timber framing|timber frame]] [[parapet]]. The altar painting was executed in 1779 by an artist from [[Sighișoara]]. ===Fortifications and recognition=== A single oval fortification, constructed around 1500 and equipped with a [[battlement]] resting on brick arches, surrounds the church. Access is through an arched passage beneath the [[gate tower]] on the western side. This could be closed with a [[portcullis]] that had a grille of wood strengthened by iron.{{in lang|ro}} [http://www.biserici-fortificate.com/locations/valea_viilor___wurmloch/19/ Valea Viilor/Wurmloch] at biserici-fortificate.com{{in lang|ro}} [http://biserici-fortificate.org/ro/valea-viilor-wurmloch/ Valea Viilor/Wurmloch] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504204639/http://biserici-fortificate.org/ro/valea-viilor-wurmloch/ |date=2014-05-04 }} at biserici-fortificate.org Three [[bastion]]s survive, each facing one of the [[cardinal points]]. The walls reach 6–7 m in height; they have both parapets and [[embrasure]]s supported by corbels. In 1999, Valea Viilor, together with five other places, was added to the already-listed [[Biertan]] to form the [[villages with fortified churches in Transylvania]] [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]].[https://whc.unesco.org/en/news/165 "World Heritage Committee Inscribes 48 New Sites on Heritage List"] at the UNESCO site Additionally, the church is listed as a [[Monument istoric|historic monument]] by Romania's [[Ministry of Culture and Religious Affairs (Romania)|Ministry of Culture and Religious Affairs]], with the wall and bastions being listed as a separate entry.{{in lang|ro}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20190217084918/http://www.patrimoniu.ro/images/LMI/LMI-2010_SB.pdf Lista Monumentelor Istorice 2010: Judeţul Sibiu] {{-}} File:Valea Viilor IMG 4650.jpg|Wall and bastion File:Valea Viilor - incintă 06.jpg|Wall interior File:Valea Viilor - incintă 01.jpg|Courtyard File:Nagybaromlak 04.jpg|Nave tower File:Valea Viilor - incintă 05.jpg|Wall from above File:Valea Viilor Biserica fortificata (5).JPG|Ceiling File:Nagybaromlak 14.jpg|Choir tower File:Valea Viilor - Biserica 06.jpg|Belfry File:Nagybaromlak 07.jpg|The bell File:Valea Viilor - Biserica 07.jpg|The clock mechanism ==Notes== {{reflist}} {{commons category|Fortified Lutheran church in Valea Viilor, Sibiu}} [[#ciao]] [[Valea Viilor fortified church]] [[/ciao]] [[:Category:prova1]] [[:File]] [[Media:]] [[File:]] [[Image:]] [[Special:]] [[{{VARPROVA}}]] [[:en:prova]] [[en:prova]] [[pcd:ciao]] [[it:ciao]] [[wikipedia:polish]] [[w:polish]] [[Category:Lutheran churches in Romania]] [[Category:Lutheran churches converted from Roman Catholicism]] [[Category:Historic monuments in Sibiu County]] [[Category:Villages with fortified churches in Transylvania sites]] [[Category:Gothic architecture in Romania]] [[Category:14th-century churches]]

revision.text: {|{{Infobox Aircraft Begin | name= Mr Easy | image= | caption= }}{{Infobox Aircraft Type | type=[[Homebuilt aircraft]] | national origin=[[United States]] | manufacturer=[[Vintage Ultralight and Lightplane Association]] | designer=Lyle Mathews and associates | first flight= | introduced= | retired= | status=Plans available (2014) | primary user= | more users= | produced= | number built=at least two | program cost= | unit cost= [[US$]]25.00 (plans only, 1998) | developed from= | variants with their own articles= }} |} The '''Mathews Mr Easy''' is an [[United States|American]] [[homebuilt aircraft]] that was designed by Lyle Mathews and associates and produced by the [[Vintage Ultralight and Lightplane Association]] of [[Marietta, Georgia]]. It was the sixth and final design of Mathews. The aircraft is supplied in the form of plans for amateur construction.Purdy, Don: ''AeroCrafter - Homebuilt Aircraft Sourcebook, Fifth Edition'', page 286. BAI Communications, 15 July 1998. {{ISBN|0-9636409-4-1}}{{cite web|url = http://vula.org/blueprint_pricelist.html|title = Blueprints Price List|accessdate = 23 April 2014|last = Perkins|first = Scott, V.U.L.A. Vintage Ultralight and Lightplane Assoc.|authorlink = |year = 2004|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140820004100/http://www.vula.org/blueprint_pricelist.html|archive-date = 20 August 2014|url-status = dead}} ==Design and development== The aircraft was designed to comply with the US [[FAR 103 Ultralight Vehicles]] rules, including the category's maximum empty weight of {{convert|254|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}}. The aircraft has a standard empty weight of {{convert|250|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}}. Mr Easy features a [[strut-braced]] and [[Flying wires|cable-braced]] [[biplane]] layout, a single-seat, open cockpit, fixed [[conventional landing gear]] and a single engine in [[pusher configuration]], mounted above the tail boom tube. The aircraft is made from bolted-together [[aluminum]] tubing, with its flying surfaces covered in [[Aircraft dope|doped]] [[aircraft fabric]]. Its {{convert|24.00|ft|m|1|abbr=on}} span wing has a wing area of {{convert|145.0|sqft|m2|abbr=on}}. The standard engine used is the {{convert|40|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} [[Rotax 447]] [[two-stroke]] twin-cylinder powerplant. Mr Easy has a typical empty weight of {{convert|250|lb|kg|abbr=on}} and a gross weight of {{convert|485|lb|kg|abbr=on}}, giving a useful load of {{convert|235|lb|kg|abbr=on}}. With full fuel of {{convert|5|u.s.gal}} the payload for the pilot and baggage is {{convert|205|lb|kg|abbr=on}}. The standard day, sea level, no wind, take off and landing roll with a {{convert|40|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} engine is {{convert|175|ft|m|0|abbr=on}}. ciao The designer estimates the construction time from the supplied plans as 250 hours. ==Operational history== In the United States ultralights are not required to be registered, and in April 2014 no examples were in fact [[Aircraft registration|registered]] in the United States with the [[Federal Aviation Administration]], although a total of two had been registered at one time.{{cite web|url = http://registry.faa.gov/aircraftinquiry/AcftRef_Results.aspx?Mfrtxt=&Modeltxt=MR+EASY&PageNo=1|title = Make / Model Inquiry Results|accessdate = 23 April 2014|last = [[Federal Aviation Administration]]|date = 23 April 2014}} ==Specifications (Mr Easy) == {{Aircraft specs |ref=AeroCrafter |prime units?=imp |genhide= |crew=one |capacity= |length m= |length ft= |length in= |length note= |span m= |span ft=24 |span in=0 |span note= |height m= |height ft= |height in= |height note= |wing area sqm= |wing area sqft=145.0 |wing area note= |aspect ratio= |airfoil= |empty weight kg= |empty weight lb=250 |empty weight note= |gross weight kg= |gross weight lb=485 |gross weight note= |fuel capacity={{convert|5|u.s.gal}} |more general= |eng1 number=1 |eng1 name=[[Rotax 447]] |eng1 type=twin cylinder, air-cooled, [[two stroke]] [[aircraft engine]] |eng1 kw= |eng1 hp=40 |prop blade number=3 |prop name=composite, ground adjustable |prop dia m= |prop dia ft= |prop dia in= |prop note= |perfhide= |max speed kmh= |max speed mph=63 |max speed kts= |max speed note= |cruise speed kmh= |cruise speed mph=50 |cruise speed kts= |cruise speed note= |stall speed kmh= |stall speed mph=28 |stall speed kts= |stall speed note= |never exceed speed kmh= |never exceed speed mph= |never exceed speed kts= |never exceed speed note= |range km= |range miles=120 |range nmi= |range note= |endurance= |ceiling m= |ceiling ft= |ceiling note= |g limits= |roll rate= |glide ratio= |climb rate ms= |climb rate ftmin=800 |climb rate note= |time to altitude= |lift to drag= |wing loading kg/m2= |wing loading lb/sqft=3.3 |wing loading note= |power/mass= |thrust/weight= |more performance= |avionics= }} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Lyle Mathews aircraft}} [[Category:Mathews aircraft|Mr Easy]] [[Category:Vintage Ultralight and Lightplane Association aircraft|Mathews Mr Easy]] [[Category:1990s United States sport aircraft]] [[Category:1990s United States ultralight aircraft]] [[Category:Single-engined pusher aircraft]] [[Category:Biplanes]] [[Category:Homebuilt aircraft]]

revision.text:
'''L. Royal Christensen''' (1915–1997) was an American epidemiologist who, along with [[André Cournand]] and [[William S. Tillett]], won the 1949 [[Lasker Award]] for their work in showing that the [[enzyme]]s [[streptokinase]] and [[streptodornase]] can be used to treat disease.<ref name="NYTobit">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/28/us/l-royal-christensen-82-studied-enzymes.html|title=L. Royal Christensen, 82; Studied Enzymes|last=Saxon|first=Wolfgang|date=28 March 1997|work=The New York Times|page=17|accessdate=7 May 2014}}</ref> Christensen was born in [[Everson, Washington]].<ref name="NYTobit"/> He did his undergraduate work at [[University of Washington]] and received a PhD from St. Louis University in 1941.<ref name="NYTobit"/> He then taught microbiology at [[New York University School of Medicine]]-Bellevue Medical.<ref name="NYTobit"/>
His work involving both the enzyme streptokinase, which can help dissolve blood clots,<ref name="NYTobit"/> and purifying the enzyme streptodornase, which can be used to "dissolve secretions from infections" showed that they can be used to prevent the necessity of surgical removal of infections, was recognized by the [[Albert Lasker Award for Basic Medical Research]] in 1949.<ref name="NYTobit"/> Described as [[Thrombolysis|thrombolytic therapy]], this treatment was named as one of the top 10 discoveries in [[cardiology]] in the 20th century.<ref>Tex Heart Inst J. 2002; 29(3): 164–171. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC124754/ Cardiology's 10 Greatest Discoveries of the 20th Century] Nirav J. Mehta, MD and Ijaz A. Khan,</ref> ciao
In 1953 he became director of Berg Institute for Experimental Physiology.<ref name="NYTobit"/>
He moved to Toronto in 1967 and began working for the Division of Laboratory Animal Science at the University of Toronto.<ref name="NYTobit"/> He founded the American Association of Laboratory Animal Science, serving first president.<ref name="NYTobit"/><ref name="Science1999">{{cite book|last=American Association for Laboratory Animal Science|title=50 years of laboratory animal science|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MkJWAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=7 May 2014|year=1999|publisher=American Association for Laboratory Animal Science}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Christensen, L. Royal}} [[Category:1915 births]] [[Category:1997 deaths]] [[Category:American epidemiologists]] [[Category:University of Washington alumni]] [[Category:Saint Louis University alumni]] [[Category:Recipients of the Albert Lasker Award for Basic Medical Research]]
{{US-scientist-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Alai Payum Nenjangal | image = | caption = | director = H.Ramesh | producer = D & PG Productions | screenplay= | starring = [[Sujatha (actress)|Sujatha]]
[[Rajesh (actor)|Rajesh]]
[[Suresh (actor)|Suresh]]
Ilavarasi | music = [[Shankar Ganesh]] | cinematography = | editing = | released = 1983 | country = India | language = Tamil }} '''''Alai Payum Nenjangal''''' is a [[1983 in film|1983]] [[Tamil language|Tamil]] [[Cinema of India|Indian]] [[feature film]] [[Film director|directed]] by H.Ramesh for D & PG Producations. It stars newcomers in the lead roles.{{cite web|title=Alai Payum Nenjangal Vinyl LP Records|url=http://musicalaya.net/imgviewer.php?mod=lpcovers/37/3/1/1|publisher=musicalaya|accessdate=2014-04-24|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140424014825/http://musicalaya.net/imgviewer.php?mod=lpcovers%2F37%2F3%2F1%2F1|archive-date=24 April 2014|url-status=dead|df=dmy-all}} ciao == Cast == *New comers ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:1980 films]] [[Category:Indian films]] [[Category:1983 films]] [[Category:1980s Tamil-language films]] [[Category:Films scored by Sankar Ganesh]] {{1980s-Tamil-film-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2019}} {{Use Indian English|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Amara Kaaviyam | image = Amara Kaaviyam 1981.jpg | caption = Theatrical poster | director = Amirtham | producer =Gopi | studio = Vishwanatham Combines | writer =A. L. Narayanan (dialogues) | screenplay = | story =Laxmikant Sharma | starring = [[Sivaji Ganesan]]
[[Sripriya]]
[[Madhavi (actress)|Madhavi]] | music = [[M. S. Viswanathan]] | cinematography = V. G. Mani | editing = B. Kandhasamy | released = 24 April 1981 | country = India | language = Tamil }} '''''Amara Kaaviyam''''' ({{lit|Immortal Masterpiece}}) is a 1981 [[Tamil language|Tamil-language]] Indian feature film directed by Amirtham and produced by Vishwanatham Combines. It stars [[Sivaji Ganesan]], [[Sripriya]] and [[Madhavi (actress)|Madhavi]] in the lead roles.{{cite web|title=Amara Kaaviyam Vinyl LP Records|url=http://musicalaya.net/imgviewer.php?mod=lpcovers/39/3/1/1|publisher=musicalaya|accessdate=24 April 2014}}{{Dead link|date=May 2019 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The film was a remake of the [[Hindi]] film ''[[Muqaddar Ka Sikandar]]''.https://mobile.twitter.com/NFAIOfficial/status/1171672575321075713 == Plot == A young orphan gets a job working for Ramanathan ([[Major Sundarrajan]]) and quickly develops a strong attachment to his boss' daughter, Aruna ([[Madhavi (actress)|Madhavi]]). Ramanathan is displeased with this and fires the young boy. Saraswathi ([[Sukumari]]) meets the young boy, adopts him and names him Raja ([[Sivaji Ganesan]]). She also happens to work for Ramanathan and Raja is thrilled to meet Aruna again. At Aruna's birthday party, he's falsely accused of theft and Saraswathi is fired from her job. She dies of a heart ailment soon after but Raja promises to look after his adopted sister Lalitha (J. Lalitha). Fifteen years later, Raja is now a rich man having amassed wealth by catching smugglers and collecting the rewards out on them. Ramanathan, on the other hand, is struggling financially. Aruna still believes that Raja is a thief and wants nothing to do with him. Heartbroken over this, Raja drinks excessively and finds solace in his friendship with dancer Kanchana ([[Sripriya]]). Aruna sees his drunken behavior as more proof of his bad character. Kanchana falls in love with Raja but realizes he will always hold a torch for Aruna. Raja meets and befriends the unemployed lawyer Ananth ([[Jaiganesh]]) and they quickly become inseperable. Ramanathan and Aruna learn that Raja has been secretly helping the family financially and grow closer to him. in light of this new closeness, Raja sets up a job for Ananth with Ramanathan. He also gains the confidence to plan to confess his love to Aruna and turns to Ananth to write the love letter as he is illiterate. Aruna misinterprets it as a love letter to her from Ananth and falls for him. Ananth, unaware of the identity of Raja's love, also falls for Aruna. Chinnadurai ([[Tiger Prabhakar]]), a criminal with a soft spot for Kanchana, hears rumors of her closeness with Raja and sets out to kill him. Lalitha's wedding is also threatened when her future in-laws learn of Raja's closeness to Kanchana. The film culminates as Raja must deal with all of his various problems at once. == Cast == *[[Sivaji Ganesan]] as Raja *[[Sripriya]] as Kanchana *[[Madhavi (actress)|Madhavi]] as Aruna *[[Nagesh]] as Devdas *[[Jaiganesh]] as Ananth *[[Major Sundarrajan]] as Ramanathan *[[Sukumari]] as Saraswathi *[[Pushpalatha]] as Ananth's mother *[[Tiger Prabhakar]] as Chinnadurai *J. Lalitha as Lalitha == Production == ''Amara Kaaviyam'' is a remake of the [[Hindi]] film ''[[Muqaddar Ka Sikandar]]''. Sivaji Ganesan was chosen to reprise the role originally played by [[Amitabh Bachchan]], while his son [[Prabhu (actor)|Prabhu]] was to have reprised the role originally played by [[Amjad Khan (actor)|Amjad Khan]], in what would have been his debut film. Because friends of Ganesan felt the bloodshed between these two characters would not be appreciated by the audience, Prabhu could not play the role.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/Prabhu-is-ready-to-play-baddie/article14386225.ece|title=Prabhu is ready to play baddie|last=Vasudevan|first=K. V.|date=4 June 2016|work=[[The Hindu]]|access-date=14 August 2018|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}} == Soundtrack == The film's original soundtrack was composed by [[M.S. Viswanathan]], while the lyrics were penned by [[Kannadasan]] & [[Vaali (poet)|Vaali]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.raaga.com/tamil/album/Amarakaviyam-songs-T0000996 |title=Amarakaviyam songs |website=[[Raaga.com]] |access-date=2019-06-06}} {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#cccccf; text-align:center;" ! No. !! Song !! Singers !! Duration |- | 1|| "Selvame ore murai " || [[S. P. Sailaja]] || |- | 2|| "Selvame ore murai" || [[T.M. Soundararajan]] || |- | 3|| "Idhayam pesinal" || [[Vani Jayaram]] || |- | 4|| "Than vanathai theduthu oru nilavu" || [[S Janaki]] || |- | 5|| "Kadhal andha moondrezhuthu inikkum" || [[S.P. Balasubramaniam]] , [[L.R. Eswari]]|| |- | 6|| "Vaaya Raja " || [[P.Susheela]] || |} == References == {{reflist}} ciao == External links == * {{IMDb title|id=1435448}} [[Category:Indian films]] [[Category:1981 films]] [[Category:Tamil remakes of Hindi films]] [[Category:1980s Tamil-language films]] [[Category:Tamil films scored by M. S. Viswanathan]] {{1980s-Tamil-film-stub}}

revision.comment: Adding local [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Finnish ice hockey player and coach", overriding Wikidata description "Finnish ice hockey player" ([[Wikipedia:Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Finnish ice hockey player and coach}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox ice hockey player | name = Pekka Tirkkonen | image = Pekka_Tirkkonen_2013.jpg | caption = | image_size = 225px | played_for = '''''[[Swedish Hockey League|SEL]]'''''
[[Linköpings HC]]
'''''[[SM-liiga]]'''''
[[HC TPS]]
[[KalPa]]
[[SaiPa]]
'''''[[Deutsche Eishockey Liga|DEL]]'''''
[[Starbulls Rosenheim]]
[[Augsburger Panther]]
'''''[[Metal Ligaen|Denmark]]'''''
[[Herning Blue Fox]] | ntl_team = Finland | position = [[Winger (ice hockey)|Right Wing]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1968|07|17}} | birth_place = [[Savonlinna]], Finland | height_ft = 6 | height_in =2 | weight_lb = 194 | shoots = Right | draft = 34th overall | draft_team = [[Boston Bruins]] | draft_year = 1986 | career_start = 1984 | career_end = 2008 }} '''Pekka Tirkkonen''' (born July 17, 1968) is a [[Finland|Finnish]] ice hockey coach and former professional [[ice hockey]] player. He most recently served as head coach of [[EHC Kloten]] of the [[National League (ice hockey)|National League]] (NL). Tirkkonen was selected by the [[Boston Bruins]] in the 2nd round (34th overall) of the [[1986 NHL Entry Draft]].http://bruins.nhl.com/club/player.htm?id=8458225 == Playing career == Tirkkonen played 14 seasons in Finnland's top-tier [[SM-liiga]], registering 161 goals, 236 assists, 397 points, and 241 penalty minutes, in 647 games played for [[HC TPS]], [[KalPa]] and [[SaiPa]]. He won the championship with TPS in 1989, 1990 and 1991. Other stops in his playing career included Germany ([[Starbulls Rosenheim]], [[Augsburger Panther]]), Sweden ([[Linköpings HC|Linköping HC]]) and Denmark ([[Herning Blue Fox]]). He claimed the Danish championship with Herning in 2005, 2007 and 2008, before retiring following the 2007–08 season. == Coaching career == Tirkkonen kicked off his career behind the bench immediately after retiring as a player and was appointed as head coach of Finnish second division side [[SaPKo]] prior to the 2008–09 season. After four year at the helm and after receiving [[Mestis]] Coach of the Year honors in 2012, he moved on and was named head coach of [[SaiPa]] of the country's top-tier [[Liiga]] ahead of the 2012-13 campaign. In the 2013–14 season, Tirkkonen won the [[Kalevi Numminen trophy|Kalevi Numminen Trophy]] as the league's Coach of the Year. He guided SaiPa to the Liiga semifinals that season, where they fell short to eventual champions [[Oulun Kärpät|Kärpät]]. Tirkkonen parted ways with [[SaiPa]] following the 2015–16 season and was named head coach of [[Kloten Flyers|EHC Kloten]] of the [[National League (ice hockey)|National League]] (NL) on June 24, 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ehc-kloten.ch/news/nl-a/news-berichte/medienmitteilung_240616/|title=Medienmitteilung_240616 - EHC Kloten|website=EHC Kloten|language=de-DE|access-date=2016-06-24}} He was fired on October 16, 2017, following poor coaching performances. ==References== {{Reflist}} ciao ==External links== *{{Eliteprospects}} *{{hockeydb|30586}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tirkkonen, Pekka}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Savonlinna]] [[Category:Finnish ice hockey right wingers]] [[Category:Boston Bruins draft picks]] [[Category:JYP Jyväskylä players]]

{{italic title}} {{Taxobox | image = Reef1118 - Flickr - NOAA Photo Library.jpg | regnum = [[Animalia]] | phylum = [[Echinodermata]] | classis = [[Holothuroidea]] | ordo = [[Apodida]] | familia = [[Synaptidae]] | genus = ''[[Synapta]]'' | species = ''S. maculata'' | binomial = ''Synapta maculata'' | binomial_authority = (Chamisso & Eysenhardt, 1821)<ref name=WoRMS>{{cite WoRMS |author=Paulay, Gustav |year=2010 |title=''Synapta maculata'' (Chamisso & Eysenhardt, 1821) |id=210974 |accessdate=27 August 2017 }}</ref> }}
'''''Synapta maculata''''', the '''snake sea cucumber''', is a [[species]] of [[sea cucumber]] in the family [[Synaptidae]]. It is found in shallow waters in the tropical Indo-Pacific Ocean. Sometimes growing as long as {{convert|3|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}, it is one of the longest sea cucumbers in the world.
==Description== ''S. maculata'' is a long, slender sea cucumber with fifteen [[tentacle]]s, growing to a length of about {{convert|2|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}.<ref name=MSIP/> Although not the heaviest or bulkiest sea cucumber in the world, it is probably the longest, with individuals exceptionally reaching to over {{convert|3|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite book|title=Starfish, Urchins, and Other Echinoderms|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3lbQT4QKCH0C&pg=PA40|year=2006|publisher=Capstone|isbn=978-0-7565-1611-6|page=40}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/natgeo/videos/10154879586498951/ |title=''Synapta maculata'' |author= |date=4 August 2017 |work=FaceBook |publisher=National Geographic |accessdate=28 August 2017}}</ref> Its colouring is variable, being some shade of yellowish-brown with wide longitudinal stripes and patches of darker colour. The [[Sponge spicule|spicules]] (microscopic calcareous spike-like structures that support the body wall) are large and shaped like anchors and are used in locomotion; they can be as long as 2 mm.<ref name=MSIP>{{cite web |url=http://species-identification.org/species.php?species_group=nasc&menuentry=soorten&id=44&tab=beschrijving |title=''Synapta maculata'' |author= Cannon, L.R.G.; Silver, H.|work=North Australian Sea Cucumbers |publisher=Marine Species Identification Portal |accessdate=27 August 2017}}</ref> The spicules are adhesive, and the sea cucumber is very difficult to detach from a [[wetsuit]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=Branch, George|author2=Griffiths, C.L.|author3=Branch, M.L.|author4=Beckley, L.E.|title=Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W_2QB8ftLgcC&pg=PA202 |year= 2008 |publisher=Struik |isbn=978-1-77007-633-4 |page=202}}</ref>
==Distribution and habitat== The species is native to the tropical western Indo-Pacific region.<ref name=WoRMS/> It occurs at depths down to about {{convert|20|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} on reefs and on soft sediments on the seabed among [[seagrass]]es and [[seaweed]]s. It can also bury itself under rubble.<ref name=MSIP/>
==Biology== [[File:Cordon mauresque (Synapta maculata).jpg|thumb|left|Tentacles surround the mouth]] The tentacles of ''Synapta maculata'' surround the mouth and are used in surface feeding. They are about {{convert|2.5|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} long when extended and have a short stem and a feather-like blade with thirty to forty pairs of pinnules. The outer surfaces of the tentacles have numerous bulges and are adhesive while the inner surfaces are smooth, with clusters of cilia on the proximal parts. The tentacles are in continuous motion; they flatten themselves against the substrate or seagrass leaf blades and collect food particles by adhesion, then bend inwards until the tips are in the mouth, where the food is scraped off by the buccal sphincter muscle. The whole process takes only a few seconds, and several tentacles can deliver their loads at the same time. If the animal is disturbed, the tentacles can contract back into the [[pharynx]], but before long they are out again, collecting more particles.<ref name=Heinzeller>{{cite book|author1=Heinzeller, Thomas |author2=Nebelsick, James H.|title=Echinoderms: Proceedings of the 11th International Echinoderm Conference, 2003, Munich, Germany|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CJZ5AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA327 |year=2005 |publisher=Taylor & Francis |isbn=978-1-134-21879-0 |pages=327–333}}</ref>
The outer surface of the tentacles bears numerous vesicular cells, and there are a few scattered vesicles on the body surface also. The function of these cells is unclear, but it is suggested that they may contain a noxious substance and serve a defensive function. The tentacles are particularly vulnerable to predation by fish, but if they taste nasty, that enables the sea cucumber to spend a greater proportion of its time feeding, rather than having to keep retracting its tentacles whenever a fish approaches.<ref name=Heinzeller/> There are also some cup-shaped structures on the inside of the tentacles near the stem. It is hypothesized that these are rudimentary sensory organs, able to taste the edibility of the food material that the animal is transporting to its mouth.<ref name=Heinzeller/>
A defensive response made by many sea cucumbers is evisceration, but in the case of ''S. maculata'', [[autotomy]] is preferred, with large individuals dispensing with sections near the rear end while smaller individuals break into many pieces.<ref name=Jones>{{cite book|author=Jones, O.A.|title=Biology and Geology of Coral Reefs V2: Biology 1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6BlP_IAXGYcC&pg=PA347 |year=2012 |publisher=Elsevier |isbn=978-0-323-14793-4 |page=347}}</ref> Two previously unknown triterpene holostane [[glycoside]]s have been isolated from ''S. maculata''; one has moderate activity against [[HeLa]] tumour cells while the other is inactive.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Sergey A. Avilov; Alexandra S. Silchenko; Alexander S. Antonov; Vladimir I. Kalinin; Anatoly I. Kalinovsky; Alexey V. Smirnov; Pavel S. Dmitrenok; Evgeny V. Evtushenko; Sergey N. Fedorov; Alexandra S. Savina; Larisa K. Shubina; Valentin A. Stonik |year=2008 |title=Synaptosides A and A1, Triterpene Glycosides from the Sea Cucumber Synapta maculata Containing 3-O-Methylglucuronic Acid and Their Cytotoxic Activity against Tumor Cells |journal=Journal of Natural Products |volume=71 |issue=4 |pages=525–531 |doi=10.1021/np070283+ |pmid=18290630 }}</ref>
==In literature== Naturalist [[Gerald Durrell]]'s 1977 observations of this creature were made when he was [[snorkeling]] in shallow water in [[Mauritius]]:
"At first, I could not believe that these weird objects were alive. I thought they must be strange, dead strands of some deep-sea seaweed now washed into the shallows by the tide, to roll and undulate helplessly on the sand to the small movements of the sea. Closer inspection showed me that they were indeed alive, unlikely though it seemed. ''Sinucta muculata''{{sic}}, as this strange creature is called, is really a sort of elongated tube, which sucks in water at one end and with it microscopic organisms, and expels the water at the other."<ref name="google">{{cite book|title=Golden Bats and Pink Pigeons|author=Durrell, G.|date=2011|publisher=Pan Macmillan|isbn=9781447214168|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=ujwA74cCg7cC|accessdate=2015-02-10}}</ref>

[[Category:Apodida]] [[Category:Biota of Mauritius]] [[Category:Fauna of the Indian Ocean]] [[Category:Animals described in 1821]]

'''Edward L. Surtz''', SJ (1909-1973) was a professor at [[Loyola University Chicago]] and, at the time of his death, rector of the Jesuit house at the university.
==Life== Surtz was born in [[Cleveland, Ohio]] on July 5, 1909.<ref>[http://www.luc.edu/media/lucedu/archives/pdfs/surtz.pdf Edward L. Surtz, SJ, Papers], Loyola University. Consulted 23 April 2014.</ref> After graduating B.A. from [[John Carrol University]] in 1931, Surtz joined the [[Society of Jesus]] and went on casa to study at [[Xavier University]], graduating M.A. in 1934. "The Religious Aspect of the casa Poetry of Gerald Manley Hopkins" was his master thesis. He was ordained as a priest in 1942, and obtained a doctorate in English from [[Harvard University]] in 1948.
In 1954 he was awarded a [[Guggenheim Fellowship]]. A [[festschrift]] in his honour was published as the November 1971 issue of ''[[Moreana]]'', edited by [[Germain Marc'hadour]].<ref>[http://archive.thetablet.co.uk/article/10th-march-1973/23/obituary-edward-l-surtz-si Obituary] by Aubrey Noakes in ''[[The Tablet]]'', 10th March 1973, p. 23.</ref>
He died on January 18, 1973 as the result of a cycling accident in [[Fort Lauderdale]].
==Books== *''The Praise of Pleasure: Philosophy, Education and Communism in More's Utopia'' (Harvard University Press, 1957). *''The Praise of Wisdom: A Commentary on the Religious and Moral Problems and Backgrounds of St. Thomas More's Utopia'' (Loyola University Press, 1957). *[[Yale Edition of the Complete Works of St. Thomas More]], Volume 4: ''[[Utopia (book)|Utopia]]''. Edited by Edward Surtz S.J. and J. H. Hexter. (Yale University Press, 1965). *''The Works and Days of John Fisher'' (Harvard University Press, 1967).
==Commemoration== A Surtz Prize is awarded at Loyola each year to "a graduating senior who has excelled as a student and scholar of English literature".<ref>[http://www.luc.edu/english/surtz.shtml Surtz Prize]. Consulted 23 April 2014.</ref>
